Yeah, as I've gotten older and wiser I've learned that you shouldn't just jump to a conclusion if you have no basis for understanding the situation. For example, I have no knowledge of the mining industry, at all. I do not know how inspections work, what various citations mean, what the industry average is..etc. Most people don't. 

 
 I do. I know ALL about it. In fact, there is a piece of paper sitting on my desk that says 
 
 US Department of Labor
 Mine Safety and Health Administration
 Office of Assessments
 PROPOSED ASSESSMENT
 
 
 What is it? It is a big, big fine from MSHA. They inspected a site I own about 2 months ago and wrote me 8 separate citations for 8 separate safety violations. 
 
 You know how many of them I intend to contest? All of them but one. Is it because I am a greedy jerk who is putting profits ahead of safety? No. It is because of the 8 citations I got only one of them is not completely and totally retarded. 
 
 The inspection took place in Feb. The mine was CLOSED in Feb. There were no workers assigned to work there. There was no activity going on. I happened to stop by there to pick up some paperwork. 10 minutes earlier or later and I would not have even seen the MSHA jerk. Instead he happened to show up at the exact right time and decided they were inspecting even though the location was closed.
 
 I immediately got a citation for not filling out a mine inspection form for the day before....despite the fact that there was nobody there to inspect the day before. Then I got a citation because a wheel loader that had JUST been delivered (that morning) and was STILL ON THE TRAILER did not have a working backup alarm or brake lights. (it turned out that the backup alarm DID work but was activated by rearward motion, not just the lever).
 
 It is idiotic citations like that which lead to operators lodging a bunch of protests and contesting their citations. 
 
 MSHA fines can be HUGE. You can LITERALLY get a $20,000.00 ticket for having an extension cord on site with worn insulation. It does not have to be worn through, or present any kind of hazard, it just has to be worn. A scuff can literally cost you 20 grand. It does not even have to be in use. It does not even have to be YOURS. It can be an extension cord that an employee has in the back of his pickup in the parking area!!!
 
 The truth is that MSHA does not save lives. If anything MSHA kills people. Backup alarms are a good example of this. It used to be that backup alarms were required on any equipment with an obstructed view to the rear. They were a good idea and almost certainly saved lives because when you heard one you sat up and took notice because you knew that somebody was backing up a machine weighing tens of tons and they did not have any idea what was behind them....they were going on faith. 
 
 Now they have changed the scope of "obstructed view to the rear" to the point that the riding lawn mower they use out there to mow around the office has a back up alarm on it. I am not even kidding.
 
 You go out there and all you hear is BEEP....BEEP....BEEP....BEEP...BEEP...BEEP...BEEP....BEEP
 It takes new employees about 2 days to learn to tune out the backup alarms completely. I have literally come within inches of being backed over by a wheel loader with a fully functional backup alarm because I just dont hear them anymore. 
 
 We have a very expensive and resource intensive program in place to combat safety related deaths. MSHA sets up training programs that hammer the guys to the point that they dont THINK about safety, they just coast through it. They have been so inundated with safety garbage that they turn off. 
 
 Why put an expensive and resource intensive program in place to combat the federally mandated safety garbage? Because the truth of the matter is that MSHA is worthless when it comes to preventing fatalities. The market and worker compensation laws pretty much did away with the "lives for profits" thing. 
 
 Reality is that if one of my people were to die, it would wipe out several years profits if not put that mine under completely. Workmans comp insurance is SO expensive if you have any past claims at all that employers are MORE than willing to put forth whatever they need to in order to assure worker safety. Granted there are jobs that are just plain dangerous and that is just the nature of the job, but employers do try their best.
 
 What is going to come out of this is the same thing that came out of the Sago disaster. People who know NOTHING AT ALL about mining like simone and who have an image in their head right out of the 1920s when it comes to mine owners and safety will freak out and a bunch of nonsensical new laws and regulations will be passed that make life even MORE dangerous for miners because these well intentioned people think they know more about mine safety than the guys who actually work in the mine. 
 
 So, Simone, should I be allowed to contest the citations from MSHA or for some reason should I not have the right that every other american has to face my accuser in court and have my case heard?
 
 The truth is that it does not matter as far as safety is concerned how many citations you contest. Here is why:
 
 When an MSHA inspector issues a safety citation you have a given period of time to get that citation vacated. For example, on my wheel loader citation he gave me 24 hours to fix the problem. If I had not fixed the problem within 24 hours he would have issued a B order, which is an order that states that the piece of equipment can not be used until the MSHA inspector has verified that the defect has been fixed. 
 
 In the case of that wheel loader, I removed the wheel loader from the site. He drove by the next day, saw it was gone, and terminated the citation.
 
 Now I am contesting the violation. It will probably be 2 years before there is a resolution but from a safety standpoint it does not matter because the underlying safety issue (if you want to pretend that is actually a safety issue) has already been fixed. 
 
 The other thing worth considering because the media has talked a lot about it is that the fines issued by MSHA are typically reduced by over 40% if you contest the violation and get it in front of an administrative judge. A lot of media outlets have implied that this is somehow improper and that the laxness of the judges is leading to unsafe conditions.
 
 Sorry. That is WRONG and ILLOGICAL. In truth, fines are typically reduced by over 40% because they were WRONG to begin with. MSHA bases fines on a point system that includes points for history of violations, size of company, gravity of the offense, and implied level of negligence. Size of the company and violation history are pretty simple. The gravity of the offense and level of negligence are not simple and they are, in large part, a judgment call. 
 
 A year ago an MSHA inspector checking my mine walked around behind a rock crusher and found (not even kidding) a guy smoking a joint. He decided that the gravity of the offense was as high as it could possibly be and so was MY negligence. I agree that the gravity of the offense was high as far as the EMPLOYEE goes, but I did not feel like I had even COMMITTED an offense. The ticket I got was HUGE.
 
 I contested the ticket and the judge decided (correctly in my opinion) that we did not have an environment at the mine that encouraged drug use...in fact we have random drug testing in place and a zero tolerance policy when it comes to drug use. He agreed with me that I had committed NO offense. We had good programs in place, we took steps to ensure that people did not use drugs, and there is no LEGAL way (not legal in kansas to strip search your employees on their way into work) for us to ensure that the event did not take place.
 
 HE also found that even if I HAD committed an offense there would have been NO negligence because the employee had gone out of their way to hide their actions from us (by hiding behind the crusher).

 Seriously, though, I am scared to death of what the blowback is going to be from this latest mining "disaster". I expect it will be severe.
 
 To date the worst (and only) injury that we have had occurred when a worker who was unloading a steel truck and failed to wear his company provided leather gloves cut his hand on a sharp piece of steel.
 
 Our federally mandated medical emergency response plan was immediately activated, as the law requires. An accident notification form was faxed to MSHA. Federal, State, and local emergency response personnel were put on standby. The 5 miners who have received EMT training assembled at our rescue rally point with trauma packs, stretchers and blankets. I was traveling and was notified and immediately called and chartered a flight back, including helicopter transportation from the airport to the mine site. 
 
 In the mean time, the injured party refused to be strapped to a stretcher for transport to the local hospital. Instead he put some neosporin on the cut and put a band aid on it from one of the 11 first aid kits that we keep on the site. 
 
 Completely and utterly retarded, but it is what federal law currently requires. Imagine what kind of BS we will have to go through if they "toughen" mine safety laws in response to this newest accident.
